Course.Title: RESEARCH & TECHNOLOGY
Course.Description: Introduction to the research process for students with majors in the Michael Graves College & School for Performing Arts. Preparation of a formal research paper. Emphasizes the use of library resources and interdisciplinary approaches to designing, investigating, and reporting research activities. Writing Intensive. College of BPM Majors Only.

Sections.CourseDescription: Introduction to the research process for students with majors in the Michael Graves College & School for Performing Arts. Preparation of a formal research paper. Emphasizes the use of library resources and interdisciplinary approaches to designing, investigating, and reporting research activities. Writing Intensive. College of BPM Majors Only.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM WKU General Education Hall A208 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: RESEARCH & TECHNOLOGY

Course.Title: WORLDS OF HISTORY
Course.Description: A seminar introducing students to the history of world civilizations and historical thinking. The course gives students an understanding of the major developments in human civilization as they relate to the relationship of the past to both the present and the future. The course teaches students to think historically by studying human change critically and analytically through the analysis of both pivotal moments in world history and the in-depth analysis of a dedicated theme.

Sections.CourseDescription: A seminar introducing students to the history of world civilizations and historical thinking. The course gives students an understanding of the major developments in human civilization as they relate to the relationship of the past to both the present and the future. The course teaches students to think historically by studying human change critically and analytically through the analysis of both pivotal moments in world history and the in-depth analysis of a dedicated theme.
MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Wednesday 10:00 AM - 11:15 AM WKU General Education Hall C204 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: WORLDS OF HISTORY

Course.Title: WITCHCRAFT IN THE WSTRN TRADT
Course.Description: The history of the belief in and fear of witches in Western civilization from ancient times to the present with an emphasis on the witch trials in Europe and America from the fifteenth through the seventeenth centuries.  Readings will focus on the intellectual, cultural, and social factors shaping the witch trials and the eventual decline of those trials.

Sections.CourseDescription: The history of the belief in and fear of witches in Western civilization from ancient times to the present with an emphasis on the witch trials in Europe and America from the fifteenth through the seventeenth centuries.  Readings will focus on the intellectual, cultural, and social factors shaping the witch trials and the eventual decline of those trials.
MeetingsDisplay: Tuesday, Thursday 10:00 AM - 11:15 AM WKU General Education Hall C209 (Lecture)
Sections.FullTitleDisplay: HIST*3845*W02 WITCHCRAFT IN THE WSTRN TRADT
Sections.Title: WITCHCRAFT IN THE WSTRN TRADT

Course.Title: SPECIAL TOPICS IN HISTORY
Course.Description: Study of a particular area of history not covered comprehensively in one of the other advanced (3000 or 4000 level) history courses. Topics to be announced by department. A student may receive credit more than once for HIST 4000 if a different topic is covered each time.

Sections.CourseDescription: Study of a particular area of history not covered comprehensively in one of the other advanced (3000 or 4000 level) history courses. Topics to be announced by department. A student may receive credit more than once for HIST 4000 if a different topic is covered each time.
MeetingsDisplay: Wednesday, Friday 2:30 PM - 3:45 PM WKU General Education Hall A205 (Lecture)
Sections.Title: Special Topics: Chinese Cinema

Course.Title: INTRO TO INDUSTRIAL DESIGN
Course.Description: A lecture course examining career and business practices in field of Industrial Design.  Emphasis on the integration of human and social factors, aesthetics, problem solving and communication skills as well as the client/designer relationship.

Sections.CourseDescription: A lecture course examining career and business practices in field of Industrial Design.  Emphasis on the integration of human and social factors, aesthetics, problem solving and communication skills as well as the client/designer relationship.

Sections.Comments: WENZHOU-KEAN STUDENTS ONLY. DESIGN AND ARCHITECTURE MAJORS ONLY.
Sections.Title: INTRO TO INDUSTRIAL DESIGN

Course.Title: HISTORY OF INDUSTRIAL DESIGN
Course.Description: A lecture course surveying the history of Indus-trial Revolution to the present, highlighting major designs movements, consumerism and the socio-political influences on modern design.

Course.Description: A studio course in design planning, material selection, execution and presentation.  Emphasis on examination of projection and presentation alternatives, and their relationship to the total design process.

Course.Title: CAD & 3-D MODELING
Course.Description: This course presents a comprehensive introduction to the methods and applications of three dimensional modeling using Computer Aided Design systems. Emphasis is placed on use of CAD hardware and software as industrial design tools in the creative problem solving process.

Course.Title: INTRO TO INTERIOR DESIGN
Course.Description: Studio experiences introducing the design and utilization of interior spaces for residential business, public and multi-use purposes; role of the interior designer in integrating social, technical, aesthetic and cultural information into the process of design. Required field experiences, fees may apply.

Sections.Title: INTRO TO INTERIOR DESIGN

Course.Title: COMPUTER-AIDED DES INTERIORS
Course.Description: An introductory studio course on the use of computer aided design applications in the field of interior design and architecture.  Includes uses of CAD technology in initial concept development, design refinement and proposal presentation.

Course.Title: INTERIOR DESIGN STUDIO I
Course.Description: Explorations of the fundamentals of interior design through the application of freehand sketching, schematic analysis, drafting and graphic presentation to problems of small scale residential or commercial settings with an emphasis on concept development and basic human factors.  Course requires competition of Sophomore portfolio continuation review.  Field experience required.  Fees may apply. Formerly: FA 3402.

Course.Title: ARCHITECTURAL LIGHTING DESIGN
Course.Description: Introductory lecture course exploring the basics of architectural lighting/electrical systems and the use of lighting as a design tool. Lighting applications in the built environment and how they interact to shape and sustain health, safety, and welfare of the public. Required field experiences, fees may apply.

Course.Description: This course studies the relationship between Interior Design and architectural systems. Construction techniques, mechanical systems, and building materials are explored. Supply fees required.

Course.Description: Studio course in the application of programming, space planning, building and life-safety codes, materials, finishes, furnishings, drafting techniques, and graphic presentation skills to the design of commercial interior and architectural environments.  Required field experiences, fees may apply.
